1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 /// <summary>
7 /// Kaufman Adaptive Moving Average (KAMA)
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// Adjusts smoothing based on market noise (Efficiency Ratio).
11 /// <list type="bullet">
12 /// <item><description>ER = Change / Volatility</description></item>
13 /// <item><description>SC = (ER * (Fast - Slow) + Slow)^2</description></item>
14 /// <item><description>KAMA = PrevKAMA + SC * (Price - PrevKAMA)</description></item>
15 /// </list>
16 /// </remarks>
17 public class KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage
18 {
19 public int Period { get; }
20 public int FastPeriod { get; }
21 public int SlowPeriod { get; }
22 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
23​
24 public KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage(int period = 10, int fastPeriod = 2, int slowPeriod = 30)
25 {
26 Period = period;
27 FastPeriod = fastPeriod;
28 SlowPeriod = slowPeriod;
29 }
30​
31 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
32 {
33 Values.Clear();
34 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
35 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
36​
37 decimal fastSc = 2.0m / (FastPeriod + 1);
38 decimal slowSc = 2.0m / (SlowPeriod + 1);
39 decimal? prevKama = null;
40​
41 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
42 {
43 if (i < Period)
44 {
45 Values.Add(null);
46 continue;
47 }
48​
49 // Step 1: Efficiency Ratio (ER)
50 decimal change = Math.Abs(candleList[i].Close - candleList[i - Period].Close);
51 decimal volatility = 0;
52 for (int j = i - Period + 1; j <= i; j++)
53 {
54 volatility += Math.Abs(candleList[j].Close - candleList[j - 1].Close);
55 }
56 decimal er = volatility != 0 ? change / volatility : 0;
57​
58 // Step 2: Smoothing Constant (SC)
59 decimal sc = er * (fastSc - slowSc) + slowSc;
60 sc = sc * sc; // Square it
61​
62 // Step 3: KAMA Calculation
63 if (!prevKama.HasValue)
64 {
65 prevKama = candleList[i].Close;
66 }
67 else
68 {
69 prevKama = prevKama.Value + sc * (candleList[i].Close - prevKama.Value);
70 }
71​
72 Values.Add(prevKama);
73 }
74 }
75​
76 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 10, int fastPeriod = 2, int slowPeriod = 30)
77 {
78 var kama = new KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage(period, fastPeriod, slowPeriod);
79 kama.Calculate(candles);
80 return kama.Values;
81 }
82 }
83}

1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Kaufman Adaptive Moving Average (KAMA) technical indicator.
7// We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8// line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9//
10// [Core Concepts]
11//
12// 1. The Problem with Fixed Moving Averages
13// [Why] Traditional MAs (SMA, EMA) use a fixed smoothing factor.
14// In trending markets: Too slow to react.
15// In choppy markets: Too many false signals (whipsaws).
16// [Solution] KAMA ADAPTS its smoothing factor based on market "efficiency".
17//
18// 2. Efficiency Ratio (ER)
19// [Formula]
20// Change = |Close[today] - Close[N days ago]| (Net direction)
21// Volatility = Sum of |Close[i] - Close[i-1]| over N days (Total noise)
22// ER = Change / Volatility
23//
24// [Interpretation]
25// ER ≈ 1 → Strong trend (price moved efficiently in one direction)
26// ER ≈ 0 → Choppy market (price zigzagged without net progress)
27//
28// [Visual]
29// Trending Market (ER ≈ 1): Choppy Market (ER ≈ 0):
30// / \/\/\/
31// / \/\/\/
32// / \/\/\/
33// Change = Volatility Change << Volatility
34//
35// 3. Smoothing Constant (SC)
36// [Formula]
37// FastSC = 2 / (FastPeriod + 1) (Highly responsive, e.g., 2 days)
38// SlowSC = 2 / (SlowPeriod + 1) (Slow, smooth, e.g., 30 days)
39// SC = [ER × (FastSC - SlowSC) + SlowSC]²
40//
41// [Why Square?]
42// Squaring dampens the effect, making KAMA even smoother in noisy markets.
43//
44// 4. KAMA Update Formula
45// [Formula] KAMA[i] = KAMA[i-1] + SC × (Close - KAMA[i-1])
46// [Same as EMA] but SC is dynamic instead of fixed.
47//
48// =============================================================================
49​
50using System;
51using System.Collections.Generic;
52​
53namespace TechnicalIndicators
54{
55 // =============================================================================
56 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container
57 // =============================================================================
58 public readonly record struct CandleData(
59 DateTime Timestamp,
60 decimal Open,
61 decimal High,
62 decimal Low,
63 decimal Close,
64 long Volume
65 );
66​
67 // =============================================================================
68 // Logic Explanation: KAMA Class
69 // =============================================================================
70 public class KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage
71 {
72 // -------------------------------------------------------------
73 // Logic Explanation: Configuration
74 //
75 // [Period] How many bars to look back for ER calculation.
76 // [FastPeriod] SC when ER = 1 (trending). Default 2.
77 // [SlowPeriod] SC when ER = 0 (choppy). Default 30.
78 // -------------------------------------------------------------
79 public int Period { get; }
80 public int FastPeriod { get; }
81 public int SlowPeriod { get; }
82 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
83​
84 // =============================================================================
85 // Logic Explanation: Constructor
86 // =============================================================================
87 public KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage(int period = 10, int fastPeriod = 2, int slowPeriod = 30)
88 {
89 if (period <= 0)
90 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period), "Period must be greater than 0");
91
92 Period = period;
93 FastPeriod = fastPeriod;
94 SlowPeriod = slowPeriod;
95 }
96​
97 // =============================================================================
98 // Logic Explanation: Main Calculation Method
99 // =============================================================================
100 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
101 {
102 // -------------------------------------------------------------
103 // Step 1: Cleanup & Setup
104 // -------------------------------------------------------------
105 Values.Clear();
106 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
107​
108 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
109​
110 // -------------------------------------------------------------
111 // Step 2: Pre-calculate Fast and Slow Smoothing Constants
112 //
113 // [Formula] SC = 2 / (Period + 1)
114 // [Why] This is the EMA multiplier formula.
115 // -------------------------------------------------------------
116 decimal fastSc = 2.0m / (FastPeriod + 1);
117 decimal slowSc = 2.0m / (SlowPeriod + 1);
118 decimal? prevKama = null;
119​
120 // -------------------------------------------------------------
121 // Step 3: Main Loop
122 // -------------------------------------------------------------
123 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
124 {
125 // [Check] Need 'Period' bars of history for ER calculation
126 if (i < Period)
127 {
128 Values.Add(null);
129 continue;
130 }
131​
132 // -------------------------------------------------------------
133 // Step 4: Calculate Efficiency Ratio (ER)
134 //
135 // [Visual: ER Calculation]
136 //
137 // Window: [Close_{i-Period}, ..., Close_i]
138 //
139 // Change = |Close[i] - Close[i-Period]|
140 // (How far did we move NET?)
141 //
142 // Volatility = Σ|Close[j] - Close[j-1]| for j in window
143 // (Total distance traveled, including zigzags)
144 //
145 // ER = Change / Volatility
146 // -------------------------------------------------------------
147
148 // [4a] Calculate Change (net movement)
149 decimal change = Math.Abs(candleList[i].Close - candleList[i - Period].Close);
150​
151 // [4b] Calculate Volatility (sum of daily movements)
152 decimal volatility = 0;
153 for (int j = i - Period + 1; j <= i; j++)
154 {
155 volatility += Math.Abs(candleList[j].Close - candleList[j - 1].Close);
156 }
157​
158 // [4c] Calculate ER (handle division by zero)
159 decimal er = volatility != 0 ? change / volatility : 0;
160​
161 // -------------------------------------------------------------
162 // Step 5: Calculate Adaptive Smoothing Constant (SC)
163 //
164 // [Formula]
165 // SC = [ER × (FastSC - SlowSC) + SlowSC]²
166 //
167 // [Logic]
168 // - When ER = 1 (trending): SC = FastSC² (responsive)
169 // - When ER = 0 (choppy): SC = SlowSC² (very smooth)
170 // - In between: Interpolated value
171 // -------------------------------------------------------------
172 decimal sc = er * (fastSc - slowSc) + slowSc;
173 sc = sc * sc; // Square for extra smoothing
174​
175 // -------------------------------------------------------------
176 // Step 6: Update KAMA
177 //
178 // [Formula] KAMA[i] = KAMA[i-1] + SC × (Close - KAMA[i-1])
179 //
180 // [First Value] Use current Close as initial KAMA.
181 // -------------------------------------------------------------
182 if (!prevKama.HasValue)
183 {
184 // Bootstrap: First KAMA is simply the current close
185 prevKama = candleList[i].Close;
186 }
187 else
188 {
189 // Recursive update (same as EMA, but with dynamic SC)
190 prevKama = prevKama.Value + sc * (candleList[i].Close - prevKama.Value);
191 }
192​
193 Values.Add(prevKama);
194 }
195 }
196​
197 // =============================================================================
198 // Logic Explanation: Static Convenience Wrapper
199 //
200 // [IPO Block]
201 // Input: IEnumerable<CandleData>, period, fastPeriod, slowPeriod
202 // Process: Creates instance, runs Calculate()
203 // Output: List of KAMA values
204 // =============================================================================
205 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 10, int fastPeriod = 2, int slowPeriod = 30)
206 {
207 var kama = new KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage(period, fastPeriod, slowPeriod);
208 kama.Calculate(candles);
209 return kama.Values;
210 }
211 }
212}

1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (Kaufman Adaptive Moving Average)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Kaufman Adaptive Moving Average (KAMA). We explain *why* code is written
7# this way and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting beginners.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. Adaptability (Signal vs. Noise)
11# Standard Moving Averages (SMA, EMA) have a fixed speed.
12# KAMA changes its speed automatically:
13# - Trend is clear (High "Efficiency") -> Speed Up (Fast MA).
14# - Market is choppy (Low "Efficiency") -> Slow Down (Stop getting whipped out).
15#
16# 2. Efficiency Ratio (ER)
17# How "straight" is the price move?
18# - ER = Net Change / Sum of All Changes.
19# - Example: Move from 10 to 20.
20# a. Straight line: 10->11->...->20. Move=10, Sum=10. ER = 10/10 = 1.0.
21# b. ZigZag: 10->15->12->18...->20. Move=10, Sum=50. ER = 10/50 = 0.2.
22#
23# 3. The Smoothing Formula
24# KAMA uses a dynamic smoothing constant (SC) based on ER.
25# Note: It squares the SC to suppress noise even more aggressively.
26#
27# =============================================================================
28​
29import math
30​
31# -------------------------------------------------------------
32# Type-Level Explanation: KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage (class)
33#
34# [Why] Stateful filter that adjusts "Alpha" (weight) dynamically.
35# [What] A noise-canceling trend filter.
36# [How] Calculates an Efficiency Ratio (ER) to gauge trend strength and dynamically adjusts the smoothing constant of an EMA, making it responsive to trends but stable during noise.
37# [Who] Perry Kaufman, Quant Systems.
38# [Where] Heap.
39# -------------------------------------------------------------
40class KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage:
41​
42 # -------------------------------------------------------------
43 # Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
44 #
45 # [Why]
46 # KAMA needs 3 inputs to define its range of speeds:
47 # 1. The window to measure "Efficiency" (ER Period).
48 # 2. The Fastest speed allowed (Fast Period).
49 # 3. The Slowest speed allowed (Slow Period).
50 # -------------------------------------------------------------
51​
52 # -------------------------------------------------------------
53 # Constructor: __init__
54 #
55 # [Input]
56 # - period: int (Default 10) - ER calculation window.
57 # - fast_period: int (Default 2) - Speed when ER=1 (Trend).
58 # - slow_period: int (Default 30) - Speed when ER=0 (Noise).
59 #
60 # [Why]
61 # Initialize implementation constants.
62 # -------------------------------------------------------------
63 def __init__(self, period=10, fast_period=2, slow_period=30):
64
65 # -------------------------------------------------------------
66 # Logic Step 1: Validation
67 # -------------------------------------------------------------
68 if period <= 0:
69 raise ValueError("Period must be > 0.")
70 if fast_period >= slow_period:
71 raise ValueError("Fast Period must be smaller than Slow Period.")
72​
73 self.period = period
74 self.fast_period = fast_period
75 self.slow_period = slow_period
76
77 self.values = []
78​
79​
80 # =============================================================================
81 # IPO: calculate
82 # =============================================================================
83 #
84 # [Input]
85 # - candles: list[dict] (Must have 'close')
86 #
87 # [Process]
88 # 1. Constant Setup: Convert Fast/Slow periods to SC constants.
89 # 2. Loop through data with a sliding window (size 'period').
90 # 3. For each window:
91 # a. Calculate Direction (Net Change).
92 # b. Calculate Volatility (Sum of Abs Changes).
93 # c. Compute Efficiency Ratio (ER = Direction / Volatility).
94 # d. Scale ER to find current Smoothing Constant (SC).
95 # e. Apply EMA formula using new SC.
96 #
97 # [Output]
98 # - None (populates self.values)
99 # =============================================================================
100 def calculate(self, candles):
101
102 # -------------------------------------------------------------
103 # Logic Step 1: Reset & Fail Fast
104 # -------------------------------------------------------------
105 self.values.clear()
106 count = len(candles)
107 if count == 0:
108 return
109​
110 # -------------------------------------------------------------
111 # Logic Step 2: Pre-calculate Bounds
112 #
113 # [Why]
114 # EMA Formula: K = 2 / (N + 1)
115 # We need the K values for the Fast and Slow limits.
116 # -------------------------------------------------------------
117 fast_limit = 2.0 / (self.fast_period + 1.0)
118 slow_limit = 2.0 / (self.slow_period + 1.0)
119 diff_limit = fast_limit - slow_limit
120​
121 prev_kama = None
122​
123 # -------------------------------------------------------------
124 # Logic Step 3: Main Loop
125 # -------------------------------------------------------------
126 for i in range(count):
127
128 # Logic Step 3.1: Wait for Data
129 # Need 'period' bars for ER calculation.
130 if i < self.period:
131 self.values.append(None)
132 continue
133​
134 # -------------------------------------------------------------
135 # Logic Step 3.2: Calculate Efficiency Ratio (ER)
136 #
137 # [Visual]
138 # Price: 10 -> 12 -> 11 -> 13
139 # Net Change (Direction): |13 - 10| = 3.
140 # Sum Change (Volatility): |2| + |1| + |2| = 5.
141 # ER = 3 / 5 = 0.6.
142 # -------------------------------------------------------------
143
144 # A. Direction (Net move over period)
145 # Uses Close[i] vs Close[i - period]
146 direction = abs(candles[i]['close'] - candles[i - self.period]['close'])
147
148 # B. Volatility (Sum of individual step moves)
149 volatility = 0.0
150 # Sum differences from (i-period+1) to i
151 for j in range(self.period):
152 # Changes adjacent bars within the window
153 step_change = abs(candles[i - j]['close'] - candles[i - j - 1]['close'])
154 volatility += step_change
155
156 # C. Ratio
157 # Guard against divide by zero (flat line)
158 er = 0.0
159 if volatility != 0:
160 er = direction / volatility
161​
162 # -------------------------------------------------------------
163 # Logic Step 3.3: Calculate Smoothing Constant (SC)
164 #
165 # [Formula]
166 # SC = [ ER * (Fast - Slow) + Slow ] ^ 2
167 #
168 # [Why Square it?]
169 # Squaring prevents the SC from rising too quickly when ER increases slightly.
170 # It keeps the moving average flat (slow) during noise (low ER),
171 # and only speeds up when ER is significantly high.
172 # -------------------------------------------------------------
173 sc = (er * diff_limit) + slow_limit
174 sc = sc * sc # Square it
175​
176 # -------------------------------------------------------------
177 # Logic Step 3.4: Recursive Update
178 #
179 # [Formula]
180 # NewKAMA = OldKAMA + SC * (Price - OldKAMA)
181 # -------------------------------------------------------------
182 current_price = candles[i]['close']
183
184 if prev_kama is None:
185 # Initialization: Start with Current Price (or SMA of period)
186 prev_kama = current_price
187 else:
188 prev_kama = prev_kama + sc * (current_price - prev_kama)
189
190 self.values.append(prev_kama)
191​
192​
193# =============================================================================
194# Functional Wrapper (Procedural Interface)
195# =============================================================================
196def calculate(candles, period=10, fast_period=2, slow_period=30):
197 """
198 Computes Kaufman Adaptive Moving Average (KAMA).
199 """
200 # 1. Instantiation
201 instance = KaufmanAdaptiveMovingAverage(period, fast_period, slow_period)
202
203 # 2. Execution
204 instance.calculate(candles)
205
206 # 3. Extraction
207 return instance.values
